title: What if grief is holy?
teaser: The honesty of lament. Permission to grieve. The psalmists didn't fake joy—they screamed at God and called it worship.
framework: Matthew 6:33 - Seek first the kingdom... and all these things will be added

panels.heading: THE SILENCING OF GRIEF
panels.content:
You've been taught that faithful people don't grieve too loudly.

Don't complain. Don't question. Don't express anger at God. If you're really trusting Him, you'll be joyful.

So when the darkness comes—when the climate crisis accelerates, when democracy fractures, when your mental health collapses—you're supposed to smile and say, "God is good."

But what happens when you can't?

What happens when the grief is too big, the fear too real, the anger too sharp?

You silence it. Suppress it. Spiritualize it away.

Because surely faithful people don't feel like this.

But here's the truth: **You've been lied to about grief.**

panels.heading: THE PSALMS OF RAGE
panels.content:
Open the Bible. Not to the happy verses. To the Psalms.

Half of them are laments. Screams. Accusations. Rage at God.

**"How long, O LORD? Will you forget me forever?"**
**"My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?"**
**"I am worn out from groaning; every night I drench my bed with tears."**

These aren't footnotes. They're Scripture. Holy text.

The psalmists didn't fake joy. They didn't spiritualize pain. They brought their rage, their grief, their terror **directly to God.**

And God included it in the Bible.

Because lament isn't the opposite of faith. **It's the language of faith in the dark.**

Grief isn't unfaithful. Denial is.

panels.heading: PERMISSION TO GRIEVE
panels.content:
Here's what you need to hear: **You have permission to grieve.**

The state of the world. The fracturing of democracy. The climate crisis. Your own mental health. Your lost dreams.

You don't have to pretend it's fine. You don't have to smile through the pain. You don't have to spiritualize away the terror.

**Grief is holy.**

It's the honest acknowledgment that something is broken. That the world isn't what it should be. That the darkness is real.

And when you bring that grief to God—not in polite whispers but in raw honesty—you're not being unfaithful.

You're doing what the psalmists did. What the prophets did. What God's people have done for millennia.

You're lamenting. And lament is a form of prayer.

illustration.description: Dithered image of person kneeling in grief, or hands raised in lament, or tears falling

panels.heading: THE PATTERN OF LAMENT
panels.content:
Biblical lament follows a pattern:

**1. Address God directly**—"O LORD, how long?"
**2. Complain honestly**—"Everything is falling apart."
**3. Ask for help**—"Save me from this darkness."
**4. Trust anyway**—"But I will hope in You."

It's not toxic positivity. It's not denial. It's **holding grief and hope together.**

You don't skip the darkness to get to the light. You bring the darkness into the light.

And somehow, in the act of honest lament, hope begins to grow.

Not because circumstances changed. But because you've stopped carrying the grief alone.

You've given it to God. And that changes everything.

panels.heading: THE PROMISE IN THE DARK
panels.content:
God doesn't ask you to pretend the darkness isn't real.

He invites you to bring it to Him.

Every fear. Every grief. Every rage at the brokenness of the world.

And here's the promise: **He can hold it.**

Your grief won't break Him. Your anger won't offend Him. Your despair won't push Him away.

Because He's not afraid of your darkness. He entered it.

And when you learn to lament—to bring your honest grief to God—you're not losing hope.

You're finding the kind of hope that can survive the dark.

The kind that doesn't deny pain but transforms it.

That's the hope the kingdom offers: **not the absence of grief, but the presence of God in it.**

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

I'm angry. I'm terrified. I'm grieving and I don't know how to hold it.

I've been told faithful people don't feel like this. But the psalmists did. So maybe I'm allowed to as well.

Here's my lament: The world is breaking. I'm scared about the future. I don't know how to hope when everything feels apocalyptic.

I'm bringing it to You. Not politely. Honestly.

Teach me to lament. To grieve faithfully. To hold darkness and hope together.

I trust You can handle my grief.

Amen.
